awd_titl_txt: US-French Research Proposal: Hippocampal Layers: Advanced Ccomputational Anatomy Using Very High Resolution MRI at 7 Tesla in Humans
awd_abstract_narration:
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) plays a pivotal role in the evaluation of brain disorders by allowing clinicians to visualize brain alterations in vivo. For instance in focal epilepsies, it allows to detect lesions that cause seizures, which can subsequently be treated surgically in patients who present drug-resistant epilepsy. This ability to unveil lesions is crucial to achieve favorable surgical outcome and may allow limiting or avoiding invasive explorations with intracerebral electrodes. However, standard MRI techniques have a limited spatial resolution, which results in limited sensitivity to detect subtle structural alterations. This is particularly true in the case of the hippocampus, a relatively small cerebral structure frequently involved in adult and adolescent temporal epilepsy, as well as in other brain disorders. Indeed, the hippocampus is composed of a complex set of internal structures whose typical size is below the resolution of conventional MRI. This project aims to develop new techniques to image the hippocampus, by combining cutting edge MRI acquisition techniques, taking advantage of higher signal to noise ratio at a ultra high magnetic field of 7 Tesla, with advanced mathematical modeling techniques. This new approach will be evaluated in patients with temporal lobe epilepsy. It is expected that exploiting to their full extent very high-resolution structural MR images will allow unveiling cerebral lesions currently undetected in conventional radiological evaluation. Furthermore, by providing unprecedented insight into hippocampal structures, this research will help developing new patient classification and new rationale to guide therapeutic choices in temporal lobe epilepsy. The proposed approach is also expected to provide critical information to advance our understanding of other brain disorders, including Alzheimer's disease and depression, which are major public health concerns. Ultimately, this will pave the way to new biomarkers for diagnosis and prognosis, and help developing new treatments.

The overall goal of this project is to develop a coherent mathematical framework for computational anatomy of the internal structures of the hippocampus based on cutting edge MRI acquisition techniques at 7 Tesla. The project introduces a new approach to move computational anatomy beyond morphometry by integrating both volumetric MRI data and shape into a single framework. To achieve this goal, the researchers will first develop MRI acquisition techniques at 7 Tesla to perform high-resolution and multi-contrast imaging, including new technical developments that will facilitate the use of these advanced methods in clinical settings, for adults and teenagers patients. The second part of the project will be devoted to the development of advanced computational techniques to model multi-contrast 7 Tesla MRI. Such techniques will be based on recent mathematical advances allowing to model multi-scale geometric deformations and to combine shape and intensity information in a coherent framework. Finally, the developed approaches will be applied to 7T MRI acquisition of patients with temporal lobe epilepsy. To that purpose, adult (in the US) and teenagers (in France) patients will be studied with 7 Tesla MRI. This should enable to demonstrate the utility of the developed techniques to unveil lesions that are undetectable by conventional means. This should result in important benefits for patients with focal epilepsy. Beyond the present project, the results should have an important impact on the diagnosis and treatment of brain conditions in which the hippocampus plays a key role, including Alzheimer's disease, depression and schizophrenia. A companion project is being funded by the French National Research Agency (ANR).

por.por_cntn:
This project was concerned with advancing techniques aiming at detecting and characterizing, in vivo, structural alterations occurring in human brain diseases, with a particular focus on hippocampal lesions and their association with epilepsy. 


The two main axes of research of this US-French Research proposal consisted of, for the team based in the USA, developing advanced structural brain image acquisition techniques at high resolution and, for the team based in France, developing advanced computational anatomy modeling of the hippocampus layers. 


For the image acquisition component, methods were developed to take advantage of MR scanners operating at Ultra-High field (7 Tesla) to achieve high resolution structural imaging while addressing technical challenges that UHF inherently entail. The main outcomes of this work concern improved image quality in T1-weighted (T1w) 3D MPRAGE data, high resolution T2-weighted Turbo Spin Echo (T2w-TSE) multislice data and whole brain Diffusion-weighted MRI (dMRI) with simultaneous multi-slice excitation. 


For T1w-MPRAGE, an MR sequence was modified to optimize non-selective inversion RF pulses, shifting their center frequency and increasing their bandwidth. This approach substantially expanded the range of brain voxels achieving proper spin inversion, a necessary condition for satisfactory T1 contrast, despite susceptibility induced off resonance frequency, particularly in the vicinity of air-tissue interfaces. Using this technique, T1w-MPAGE images were effectively devoid of susceptibility induced artifactual hyperintensities typically observed near air/tissue interfaces with the native sequence. 


For T2-TSE MRI, we improved our baseline protocol by shortening acquisition times using a GRAPPA X2 acquisition acceleration which became feasible with to the use of dielectric pads not visible in MR images ("MR transparent") allowing for shorter Left-Right Field of View reduction, thus smaller acquisition matrix size, without MR signal aliasing onto the brain. This yielded a reduction of the total acquisition time of T2-TSE images by about 40%, helping in turn to reduce the likelihood of motion artifacts while preserving high spatial resolution.


For dMRI, we successfully included in a whole brain 7 Tesla dMRI protocol the correction of k-space deviations due to diffusion encoding gradient induced eddy currents by using multi-probe magnetic field camera monitoring. We demonstrated, for the first time, a reconstruction algorithm capable of applying such corrections to diffusion data obtained with simultaneous multi-slice (SMS) excitation. The SMS strategy provides substantial data acceleration with a very limited cost in Signal to Noise, but, facing more complex issues for eddy current correction than traditional multi-slice acquisitions, required a dedicated iterative reconstruction. Applying these corrections effectively preserves sharper details and better white/gray matter delineation in high b-value DW images and in derived Fractional Anisotropy maps.  

These imaging methods have been reported in two publications (Neuroimage, Magnetic Resonance Imaging) and helped us contribute to a multi-center effort, initiated by a group of 7 Tesla equipped imaging facilities, aiming at defining consensus agreement to investigate Epileptic patients with MRI at 7 Tesla (published in Neurology). 

For the computational anatomy component, the team based in France was focusing on developing advanced methods to model hippocampal layers from 7 Tesla MRI. In particular, we developed a method to analyse the ribbon formed by the pyramidal layer (stratum pyramidale ? SP) of the hippocampus (specifically the cornu Ammonis and the subiculum). From a high-resolution 7T MRI, the structures are first delineated using a segmentation protocol that we proposed. We then introduced a new mathematical framework that reconstructs the ribbon and estimates its thickness at each point. This allowed a local analysis of atrophy patterns. We first demonstrated the robustness of our approach to anisotropy, as well as to inter-rater variability, on a post-mortem scan and on in vivo acquisitions respectively. We then applied the approach to healthy controls and patients with temporal lobe epilepsy imaged at 7T. We showed that this new method can detect local alterations in patients with epilepsy and is potentially more sensitive than conventional volumetric analysis. 


The results were published in IEEE Transactions on Biomedical Engineering and the method was made available to the community as open source software.  


All the tools developed in this US-France collaboration are expected to pave the way towards new patient classification and new rationale to guide therapeutic choices in Epilepsy. Beyond epilepsy, these approaches are also expected to provide new insights into brain disorders, including Alzheimer's disease and depression, which represent a major public health burden.
